title: VEXPANDPS â€” Load Sparse Packed Single-Precision Floating-Point Values from Dense Memory

fields.name: Instruction Modes
fields.value:
`VEXPANDPS xmm1 {k1}{z}, xmm2/m128`
`VEXPANDPS ymm1 {k1}{z}, ymm2/m256`
`VEXPANDPS zmm1 {k1}{z}, zmm2/m512`

fields.name: Description
fields.value: Expand (load) up to 16/8/4, contiguous, single-precision floating-point values of the input vector in the source operand (the second operand) to sparse elements of the destination operand (the first operand) selected by the writemask k1.

fields.name: ​
fields.value: The destination operand is a ZMM/YMM/XMM register, the source operand can be a ZMM/YMM/XMM register or a 512/256/128-bit memory location.

fields.name: ​
fields.value: The input vector starts from the lowest element in the source operand. The writemask k1 selects the destination elements (a partial vector or sparse elements if less than 16 elements) to be replaced by the ascending elements in the input vector. Destination elements not selected by the writemask k1 are either unmodified or zeroed, depending on EVEX.z.

fields.name: ​
fields.value: EVEX.vvvv is reserved and must be 1111b otherwise instructions will #UD.

fields.name: ​
fields.value: Note that the compressed displacement assumes a pre-scaling (N) corresponding to the size of one single element instead of the size of the full vector.

footer.text: Thanks to Felix Cloutier for the online x86 reference
